articles.title: Yiddish life in prewar Eastern Europe comes alive on this website
articles.description: On a quiet corner of the internet, a new website asks us to listen. That site — “https://www.yiddishculture.co/” — is more than a digital exhibit; it’s an act of cultural restitution. Each page restores the sound, movement and texture of Jewish life that once animated the streets of Poland and Lithuania, before silence fell. Yiddishculture.co.... The post Yiddish life in prewar Eastern Europe comes alive on this website appeared first on The Forward .
articles.author: Judah Sussman

articles.title: Course on Yiddish in Ukraine in the 20th century
articles.description: ווי בײַ יעדן לערן־זמן פֿון דער ווירטועלער ייִדיש־פּראָגראַם בײַם אַרבעטער רינג, וועט מען במשך פֿונעם האַרבסט־זמן 2025 לערנען אַ צאָל אינטערעסאַנטע ווײַטהאַלטער־קורסן אויף ייִדיש. דער פֿאָרשער גענאַדי עסטרײַך וועט לערנען אַ קורס וועגן דער ייִדישער ליטעראַטור אין אוקראַיִנע במשך פֿונעם 20סטן יאָרהונדערט, אַרײַנגערעכנט די שרײַבער פֿון דער „קיִעווער גרופּע“— דוד בערגעלסאָן און דער ניסתּר. מע... The post Course on Yiddish in Ukraine in the 20th century appeared first on The Forward .

articles.title: Gaza hostages developed coping mechanisms to help them survive captivity, new study shows
articles.description: After studying the testimonies of several dozen hostages who were released from captivity in Gaza, Prof. Inbar Levkovich insists that the struggle to return all of the deceased hostages is important for former captives, who see all of those who were in Gaza 'on a family level, like siblings'
articles.author: Adi Hashmonai

articles.title: Trump admin reaches agreement with UVA, lauds ‘progress’ on Jew-hatred
articles.description: "DOJ can reopen anytime if UVA goes sideways. That's common sense and a fair deal," stated Virginia Gov. Glenn Youngkin. The post Trump admin reaches agreement with UVA, lauds ‘progress’ on Jew-hatred appeared first on JNS.org .

articles.title: Doctoral program admissions at Harvard down ‘significantly’ due to financial constraints
articles.description: “To balance both our academic and fiscal responsibilities, cohort sizes will be significantly reduced as we evaluate the future model for Ph.D. education,” the dean of Harvard’s arts and sciences faculty said. The post Doctoral program admissions at Harvard down ‘significantly’ due to financial constraints appeared first on JNS.org .

articles.title: 2,700-year-old Assyrian inscription unearthed near Temple Mount
articles.description: The inscription specifies a due date, and researchers are investigating the possibility that the artifact is evidence of a tax revolt, such as that of the biblical King Hezekiah against Sennacherib. The post 2,700-year-old Assyrian inscription unearthed near Temple Mount appeared first on JNS.org .

articles.title: Biblical tax notice: 1st-ever Assyrian inscription found near Jerusalem’s Temple Mount
articles.description: 2,700-year-old fragment of pottery suggests Judeans delayed paying their tributes to the empire, echoing the events described in the book of II Kings The post Biblical tax notice: 1st-ever Assyrian inscription found near Jerusalem’s Temple Mount appeared first on The Times of Israel .

articles.title: Blood test 95% accurate in spotting suicide risk in bipolar patients, says Israeli scientist
articles.description: University of Haifa researcher says her team's AI model spots biomarkers in white blood cells; test could help monitor patients with bipolar disorder, 40% of whom will attempt suicide The post Blood test 95% accurate in spotting suicide risk in bipolar patients, says Israeli scientist appeared first on The Times of Israel .

articles.title: A sanctuary on campus: Hebrew classrooms at American universities after Oct. 7, 2023
articles.description: “I would say, anuchnu po (we are here), and the students would respond, anuchnu po beyachad (we are here together).” In the weeks after Oct. 7, 2023, this simple Hebrew call-and-response became a mantra in the classroom of one large public university. For students and their Israeli-born teacher, it was more than a language exercise:... Read More The post A sanctuary on campus: Hebrew classrooms at American universities after Oct. 7, 2023 appeared first on eJewishPhilanthropy .
articles.author: Sharon Avni

articles.title: At NYC gala, Goldman family announces $2 million matching grant to Israel’s Ben-Gurion University
articles.description: At a Manhattan benefit for Americans for Ben-Gurion University on Sunday night, the Joyce and Irving Goldman Family Foundation announced a $2 million matching grant to support the university’s recovery from the Israel-Hamas war, including the Iranian missile strike that damaged academic facilities in June. The event, held in midtown Manhattan, drew several hundred supporters... Read More The post At NYC gala, Goldman family announces $2 million matching grant to Israel’s Ben-Gurion University appeared first on eJewishPhilanthropy .
articles.author: Nira Dayanim

articles.title: Fresh data shows Israeli emigration levels far outpacing immigration over past two years
articles.description: The State of Israel is a country made up overwhelmingly of immigrants, and Jewish immigration to Israel, or aliyah, remains a central tenet of Zionism. And while aliyah has continued through the past two years of war, during this time —and in the months preceding it — Israelhas become a state of emigration, with more... Read More The post Fresh data shows Israeli emigration levels far outpacing immigration over past two years appeared first on eJewishPhilanthropy .
articles.author: Judah Ari Gross

articles.title: We cannot forget the fallen
articles.description: The images of hostages returning home, embracing their families after months of captivity, have moved us all to tears of relief and joy. We should celebrate these reunions. We must feel this happiness. But even as we rejoice, we cannot declare victory. We cannot move on. Sixteen hostages remain in Gaza, and they are not... Read More The post We cannot forget the fallen appeared first on eJewishPhilanthropy .
articles.author: Sara Fredman Aeder

articles.title: Multicultural Jewish nonprofit Be’chol Lashon 2.0 launches with anthology at New York Comic Con
articles.description: Every year, more than 200,000 fanboys and fangirls surge into Manhattan’s Jacob K. Javits Convention Center for the East Coast’s biggest ode to pop culture: New York Comic Con. When comic creator Julian Voloj accepted a position at the Jewish diversity nonprofit Bechol Lashon in 2017, he had an idea in the back of his... articles.title: The emergency isn’t over: Why Jewish philanthropy must stay in crisis mode after the war
articles.description: When I was a freshman football player, I had a coach from South Jersey whose accent sounded more like the Deep South. Whenever he thought we weren’t giving enough effort, he’d bark, “You gotta have a sense of UR-GEN-SEEE!” I’m still not sure if he added or removed a syllable, but the point always landed:... Read More The post The emergency isn’t over: Why Jewish philanthropy must stay in crisis mode after the war appeared first on eJewishPhilanthropy .
articles.author: Will Eastman

articles.title: Remembering my chavruta: Rabbi Moshe Hauer, z”l
articles.description: Earlier this week on Simchat Torah, we read the Torah’s final description of the biblical Moshe’s life of inspired leadership: “There never arose another one like Moshe” (Deuteronomy 34:10). These words carry poignant resonance as our Jewish community mourns the sudden death of our beloved sage, Rabbi Moshe Hauer, z”l. Many Jewish leaders talk about...
